docs.title: AWS Cloud Focus (Production)
docs.text:
I build and operate production platforms primarily on AWS, with deep hands-on delivery across:

  • Networking: VPC, subnets, route tables, IGW/NAT, VPC endpoints, security groups, NACLs
  • Compute & Containers: EC2, EKS, Auto Scaling, Launch Templates, ECR
  • Identity & Security: IAM, KMS, Secrets Manager/Parameter Store, CloudTrail, AWS Config (guardrails), IRSA for EKS
  • Traffic & Edge: ALB/NLB, Ingress Controllers, Route 53, ACM, WAF (when applicable)
  • Data & Messaging (as needed): RDS, DynamoDB, S3, SQS/SNS
  • Observability: CloudWatch, logs/metrics alarms, plus Datadog/Prometheus/Grafana patterns

I design and operate secure, automated cloud platforms that scale in production — with strong focus on Kubernetes (EKS/GKE), Infrastructure as Code, CI/CD reliability, observability, and security/compliance.

docs.title: AWS Platform Engineering (Deep Proof)
docs.text: This page summarizes how I design, automate, secure, and operate AWS platforms in production — with Kubernetes (EKS) at the core where container orchestration is required.

docs.title: 1) AWS Foundations (Network + Accounts)
docs.text: • AWS Platform: aws-platform.md

docs.title: VPC architecture patterns
docs.text:
• Segmented subnets (public/private), route tables, IGW/NAT
  • Private connectivity via VPC endpoints (S3/ECR/CloudWatch/etc.)
  • Security posture with security groups and controlled egress

docs.title: Environment strategy
docs.text:
• Repeatable environments via Terraform modules
  • Separation by account and/or VPC boundaries for blast-radius control

docs.title: Cluster design
docs.text:
• Managed node groups, capacity strategy (on-demand/spot where appropriate)
  • Ingress via ALB and Kubernetes ingress controller
  • Add-ons: metrics-server, external-dns (Route53), cert-manager (ACM integration patterns)

docs.title: IAM for workloads (IRSA)
docs.text:
• Workload-level permissions using IAM Roles for Service Accounts
  • No sharing node IAM credentials across workloads
  • Clear least-privilege policies per service

docs.title: Identity and auditability
docs.text:
• IAM least privilege + role-based access
  • CloudTrail for audit logs, plus centralized logging patterns
  • KMS encryption for sensitive data

docs.title: Secrets & config
docs.text:
• Secrets Manager or SSM Parameter Store (no secrets in Git)
  • Rotation discipline and access boundaries

docs.title: 4) Observability on AWS (Ops readiness)
docs.text:
• CloudWatch metrics + logs for baseline visibility
  • Alerting tied to customer impact (error rate/latency/saturation)
  • SLO-style thinking with burn-rate style alerts where applicable
  • Integration with Datadog/Prometheus/Grafana for deeper service telemetry

docs.title: 5) Reliability & Cost (practical platform ownership)
docs.text:
• Right-sizing requests/limits and node capacity to reduce waste
  • Autoscaling strategies and safe deployment patterns
  • Reduce MTTR via runbooks + rollback playbooks + postmortems
  • Cost-aware design: private endpoints, managed services, and avoiding “always-on” waste

docs.title: Security & Compliance
docs.text: I build platforms with security controls embedded into the default delivery path — so teams ship faster safely.

docs.title: Baseline security controls
docs.text:
• Least privilege IAM with role-based access and scoped policies
  • IRSA for Kubernetes workloads (no shared node credentials)
  • Encryption at rest (KMS-ready patterns) and TLS in transit
  • Segmentation: private workloads where needed, controlled ingress/egress
  • Secrets discipline: no plaintext secrets, rotation expectations, boundary-based access

docs.title: DevSecOps in the pipeline
docs.text:
• SAST + dependency scanning as required checks
  • Container image scanning with triage + remediation workflow
  • IaC scanning (tfsec/checkov-style) with actionable failures
  • Change traceability: approvals, commits, releases, and audit-friendly history

docs.title: Compliance readiness (practical)
docs.text:
• Evidence-by-design via:
  • CI/CD logs + build artifacts
  • IaC state and versioned changes
  • Release notes + change approvals
  • Runbooks + incident timelines + postmortems

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: A simple, reliable incident flow that stabilizes service quickly, keeps stakeholders informed, and drives permanent fixes.

docs.title: Severity levels
docs.text:
• SEV1: Major outage / customer impact / data risk
  • SEV2: Partial degradation / high error rates / limited blast radius
  • SEV3: Minor impact / workaround available

docs.title: Roles
docs.text:
• Incident Commander (IC): owns coordination and decisions
  • Operations Lead: drives technical triage + mitigation
  • Comms Lead: updates stakeholders and timelines
  • Scribe: records timeline, actions, and outcomes

docs.title: First 10 minutes (stabilize)
docs.text:
1. Declare severity + start incident channel/bridge
  2. Freeze risky changes (pause deploys if needed)
  3. Confirm blast radius (who/what is impacted)
  4. Identify last known good state + recent changes
  5. Execute stabilization action (rollback, scale, disable feature, failover)

docs.title: Triage checklist
docs.text:
• Deploy regression? compare to last release
  • Infra capacity? CPU/mem/node pressure/saturation
  • Dependency failure? DB/cache/external API
  • Networking/DNS/certs? timeouts/TLS errors
  • Kubernetes health? pods flapping/HPA/readiness

docs.title: Communication cadence
docs.text:
• SEV1: updates every 10–15 minutes
  • SEV2: updates every 30 minutes

docs.title: Resolution & recovery
docs.text:
• Confirm recovery with metrics + smoke tests
  • Re-enable deploys carefully
  • Capture final impact summary

docs.title: Post-incident
docs.text:
• Postmortem within 24–72 hours
  • Action items: owners + due dates + verification

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Quickly determine whether the issue is workload, cluster, network, or dependency.

docs.title: First checks (2 minutes)
docs.text:
• kubectl get pods -A | grep -E "CrashLoopBackOff|Error|Pending|ImagePullBackOff"
  • kubectl get nodes (Ready? pressure?)
  • Check recent deploys (what changed?)

docs.title: Pods flapping / CrashLoopBackOff
docs.text:
• kubectl describe pod <pod> -n <ns>
  • kubectl logs <pod> -n <ns> --previous Common causes:
  • bad config/env vars
  • missing secrets
  • failing health checks
  • dependency unavailable
  • resource limits too low

docs.title: High latency / timeouts
docs.text:
• Check ingress/ALB metrics
  • Check service endpoints:
  • kubectl get endpoints <svc> -n <ns>
  • Look for network policy changes
  • Validate DNS:
  • CoreDNS health and resolution

docs.title: Pending pods
docs.text:
• kubectl describe pod <pod> -n <ns> Common causes:
  • insufficient CPU/memory
  • node taints/tolerations
  • missing PV/PVC binding

docs.title: Node pressure
docs.text:
• kubectl describe node <node> Look for:
  • MemoryPressure / DiskPressure / PIDPressure Mitigations:
  • scale node group
  • evict noisy workloads
  • increase requests/limits accuracy

docs.title: “Golden signals” focus
docs.text: • errors, latency, saturation, traffic Tie changes to these metrics before deciding rollout/rollback.

docs.text: Action Owner Due date Verification

docs.text: List the specific guardrails, monitoring improvements, automation, or design changes that will prevent this class of issue.

docs.title: When to rollback
docs.text:
• Error rate spikes after deploy
  • Latency regression beyond threshold
  • Increased pod crashes / failed health checks
  • SLO burn-rate alerts triggered by release

docs.title: Rollback options (ranked)
docs.text:
1. Rollback to last stable version
  2. Disable feature flags (if used)
  3. Scale down new version / scale up stable
  4. Traffic shift back (canary/blue-green)

docs.title: Kubernetes rollback (examples)
docs.text:
• Helm:
  • helm history <release> -n <ns>
  • helm rollback <release> <REVISION> -n <ns>
  • Deployments:
  • kubectl rollout undo deploy/<name> -n <ns>
  • kubectl rollout status deploy/<name> -n <ns>

docs.title: Verification after rollback
docs.text:
• Confirm key endpoints
  • Validate error/latency returns to baseline
  • Watch saturation and pod stability
  • Update stakeholders with recovery confirmation

docs.title: After action
docs.text:
• Open follow-up ticket
  • Capture root cause notes
  • Schedule postmortem if SEV1/SEV2
